author: axic3354
content:
I don't want to rip up old wounds, but why can't withdrawn EIPs be revived?

And what point does it serve to wait for author's confirmation for stagnancy? It was supposed to be an automated process (without confirmation) as things can stay stagnant indefinitely, but only withdrawn by the author's request -- this was the whole argument <@!187490121698770945> made for the stagnant state. (I still think it the bot should just open a PR for withdrawn and let the author confirm or reject, or withdraw it after 1 months of no-response from the author **and** at the same time allow revival from withdrawn state.)

author: sky.cactus
content:
> I don't want to rip up old wounds, but why can't withdrawn EIPs be revived?
They can be I believe.

author: axic3354
content:
> Stagnant - Any EIP in DRAFT or REVIEW if inactive for a period of 6 months or greater is moved to STAGNANT. An EIP may be resurrected from this state by Authors or EIP Editors through moving it back to DRAFT.
> 
> EIP Authors are notified of any algorithmic change to the status of their EIP
> 
> Withdrawn - The EIP Author(s) have withdrawn the proposed EIP. **This state has finality and can no longer be resurrected using this EIP number. If the idea is pursued at later date it is considered a new proposal.**

author: sky.cactus
content:
> And what point does it serve to wait for author's confirmation for stagnancy?
We give the author 2 weeks and then we automatically merge the PR if the author doesn't say anything.

author: sky.cactus
content: Huh, I don't know then.  ðŸ˜•

author: axic3354
content: I would set a bunch of things to withdrawn from my side, **if** it can be resurrected later.

author: sky.cactus
content: I *have* set a bunch of things to withdrawn because I thought it could be resurrected later.  ðŸ˜¬

author: sky.cactus
content: Though, I also don't mind just creating a new EIP.  I never get attached to my numbers.

author: axic3354
content: It is not about the actual numbers, but the whole point this supposed to solve is reducing the number of useless EIPs. If you need to keep duplicating that is counter intuitive.

author: sky.cactus
content: Why not withdraw and then if you decide to resurrect just give a new number?

author: sky.cactus
content: You don't have to rewrite anything, just rename the EIP file in GitHub and change the status.

author: axic3354
content: Can't rename a file ðŸ™‚

author: sky.cactus
content: Why not?

author: axic3354
content: Because even in the archival proposal I think we should keep the headers intact, so it can be found. I know you strongly oppose having any kind of searchability, but even RFCs have that.

author: sky.cactus
content: Oh, you dislike losing the file changelog?

author: axic3354
content: No, I think once an EIP is merged, their number should be available on the site. If we go with the archival proposal, then the archived ones would have an archived status and only keep the headers and wouldn't be visible on the main listing, but would still be available via the direct URL.

author: sky.cactus
content: It is unclear to me why un-archiving with a new number would break that?

author: axic3354
content: Because the direct URL would break. You don't have anything at the old number anymore.

author: sky.cactus
content: Oh, the theory here is that people will have saved a link to the withdrawn/archived EIP somewhere off-site and that link will 404 once we rename/renumber the EIP?

author: axic3354
content: https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-5555 will be 404 if you rename 5555 to 6666.

author: axic3354
content: Anyway I'll just merge the stagnant ones for a few of mine and that's it. Can't spend too much time on this ðŸ™‚

author: sky.cactus
content:
So I'm generally against people putting any significant value (including linking with expectations of permanence) to non-final EIPs.  I consider mild disincentives to that behavior to be a net positive.

However, I also don't have a problem with authors being able to withdraw an EIP and then un-withdraw them later.

author: sky.cactus
content: I *think* the reason we might have done the withdraw is permanent thing is because we didn't want people re-using old numbers for new EIPs in order to get a low number (which has value to people, as it makes the EIP *appear* older than it is).

author: axic3354
content: You just really dislike any traceability and having stable URLs ðŸ™‚

author: sky.cactus
content: I just really dislike all goodness in the world and prefer chaos and suffering.

author: axic3354
content: Did this ever happen or are we making things worse for defending against something yet to happen? (Which is quite the opposite of most of the ethos of the EIP process.)

author: sky.cactus
content: We have had people on numerous occasions try to number squat.  I don't think we have seen this *specific* behavior because withdrawn EIPs weren't a thing previously.

author: axic3354
content: Number squatting is not solved by this ðŸ˜¦

author: axic3354
content: People keep doing that, opening/closing empty issues until it gets to the desired number.

author: sky.cactus
content: Correct, but it lets us know that there is demand for certain numbers and people will do bad things to get desirable numbers.  We have a suspicion that "lower is better" when it comes to EIP numbers (with weak anecdotal evidence for that).  Those combine to give us not unreasonable belief that if resurrection is allowed people will try to game it.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think if you are passionate about resurrection you could probably convince the editors.  I won't fight hard against you.

author: sky.cactus
content: And I doubt anyone else would either.

author: axic3354
content: They can easily "game" it by keeping it stagnant and just changing it whenever ðŸ™‚

author: sky.cactus
content: Maybe someone else (<@642887713246150666>?) remembers other reasons Withdrawn is considered terminal.

author: poojaranjan
content:
> And what point does it serve to wait for author's confirmation for stagnancy? 
> It was supposed to be an automated process (without confirmation) as things can stay stagnant indefinitely, but only withdrawn by the author's request
Yes, as I remember, this was the general agreement. Ref EIPIP meeting 17 [notes](https://github.com/ethereum-cat-herders/EIPIP/blob/master/All%20EIPIP%20Meetings/Meeting%20017.md)

author: poojaranjan
content: I think, I was advocating for "Withdrawn" to be a reason for deprecating an EIP and not a status, but at the time, I lost my battle and the decision was to make it a status.

author: poojaranjan
content:
However, "Stagnant" replaced the earlier status"Abandoned", which allows to let the EIP rest for a while if the proposal is inactive. 
I think asking permission from the EIP author for moving it to stagnant, is actually a process of notifying that your proposal is inactive for over 6 months.

author: poojaranjan
content: I am not sure, if leaving a proposal in "Stagnant" forever is a good idea, so I think it should be deprecated at some point. As per the current process, withdrawn is the terminal stage of an EIP.

author: poojaranjan
content: If leaving a proposal in "Stagnant" indefinitely, is helpful to authors to hang on the EIP number and bring the EIP back to life at some point in the future, then the bot can be updated accordingly.

author: sky.cactus
content: <@642887713246150666> Do you remember why we decided to make it so you cannot "resurrect" a Withdrawn EIP though?  Even if we had deprecated EIPs, what is the reason for not allowing such EIPs to be resurrected at some point in the future?

author: poojaranjan
content: "Withdrawn" was proposed by <@!187490121698770945> . Not sure if he may had some thoughts.

author: axic3354
content:
This was the competing proposal: https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/issues/2941

But then we ended up with stagnant ðŸ™‚

author: gcolvin
content: Withdrawn would seem to indicated that the authors do not want the EIP to be implemented as specified.  If the authors want to bring a changed proposal forward again it's a fuzzy call whether the changes are so large as to demand a new EIP number.
